nodes.bodyText: This is a breaking change albeit a correct change. But I would want it to be a part of a separate commit to show it on the Release notes.
I would expect a test case also to be fixed or updated, what did I miss? If there are no test cases failing due to this change, we need to add a test 😄
please revert. This is an unrelated change.

nodes.bodyText: please revert. This is an unrelated change.
please revert. This is an unrelated change.
please revert. This is an unrelated change.
Effective Java principles state that interface should be on the left hand side. Also, this should ideally be replaced by Maps.mutable.with().
same comment as above
please revert. This is an unrelated change.
please revert. This is an unrelated change.
please revert. This is an unrelated change.
Shouldn't this be in AbstractSynchronizedMapIterable ?

Thanks for your comments.
Are you expecting this method to be like this below?
public MutableBiMap<K, V> withMapIterable(AbstractSynchronizedMapIterable <? extends K, ? extends V> mapIterable)
I used MapIterable instead of AbstractSynchronizedMapIterable as it is overriding default method from MutableMap. Did I miss something here? Please correct me if I am wrong.

Sorry, let me try to rephrase it. If you check where withMap() method is implemented, this method should also be implemented in the same class. I would have expected this method to be added in the abstract class. But there might be something I might be missing, so please take a look.

Thanks for reviewing!
SynchronizedSortedMap, SynchronizedMutableMap and SynchronizedBiMap, all have custom implementations of withMap() method, so I decided to add withMapIterable() to each of these three classes. Also, AbstractSynchronizedMapIterable, the parent class, is inheriting withMap() method from MutableMapIterable but not overriding in the abstract class itself. In MutableMapIterable, we do have withMap() implemented so I added withMapIterable() to the class. Hope it makes sense. Thanks again!
The actual reason why you cannot move this implementation to the abstract class is because of the covariant return type. So, you have to add it in the implementation itself.
Same comment as SynchronizedBiMap
Same comment as SynchronizedBiMap
Please reorder this to move it around the other tests of method.
Reorder the tests please to bunch all of them together.

@donraab the return type here is a void should we return a MutableMapIterable instead of void, i.e. return a this?
The way I look at it is that, if we return a MutableMapIterable it never hurts, but if we return a void, reassigning in user code is impossible.
I prefer returning this. Thoughts?
Any case, we will take this in as void and fix it in a next PR.
Revisiting my point from earlier, I think let us have putAllMapIterable return a void because we are adding withMapIterable which is returns this.
I think putAllMapIterable should be symmetric with putAll. What does putAll return? Just looked, as I suspected, returns void.
void
Can be replaced with Maps.mutable.with() instead of UnifiedMap
Updated to use Maps.mutable.with() instead of UnifiedMap methods. Updated the same for putallmapiterable test cases too.

I dont think you need default method here because all the implementing interfaces should have a default method. It is easy to check by removing this method, or you can check the coverage and this method will be uncovered in this interface. If it is uncovered you can delete it.
That said, it is good to have default methods to help users with custom implementations, so I would say, you can add a test to cover this method. It can be done separately as a different PR.
Thanks @nikhilnanivadekar for reviewing. If you don't mind, can I do this on another PR? Thanks again for your comments!
Sure!
Same comment as the previous commit, change to Maps.mutable.with()
Updated to use Maps.mutable.with() instead of UnifiedMap methods. Updated the same for putallmapiterable test cases too.
I think we need better assertions here. It should be possible to assert with a MutableMap no?
Updated the code to handle assert with a MutableMap using Verify.assertMapsEqual() method.
This is a strange inconsistency we have. withKeyValue on a fixed-size map is capable of replacing a value at a key without growing the map, but put() always throws.

put() has to return a V (old value), so it's not possible to have a proper implementation on FixedSizedMap. On the other hand, anything that returns a map is entirely implementable. I don't see why we wouldn't implement these...

I don't see an issue with changing put to allow mutation of the value for the same key. (My point was that put can't work for the general case, i.e., an arbitrary key). The other methods work just fine for arbitrary parameters, so throwing is particularly strange there.
For some reason, I thought the small maps were immutable, probably remembering really ancient code? On the mutable side, mutations can be allowed as long as the map size doesn't change.
Tagging @nsardana-bny @nikhilnanivadekar @donraab for attention.
